page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 154: Line 154:
On the 14 July, former President [[Hosni Mubarak]] told prosecutors that he did not order security forces to open fire on protesters during the 18-day uprising that forced him to resign in February. Transcripts of prosecutors questioning Mubarak were published in two Egyptian newspapers but judicial officials confirmed the authenticity of the documents.<ref name="voanews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html |title=Egyptian Media: Mubarak Denies Ordering Police to Fire on Protesters | Middle East | English |publisher=Voanews.com |date=2011-07-14 |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> Mubarak says he issued clear instructions for police not to use force against people taking part in the protests against his three-decade autocratic rule. He denied charges that he ordered or had knowledge of security forces firing on the demonstrators.<ref name="voanews1"/>
On the 14 July, former President [[Hosni Mubarak]] told prosecutors that he did not order security forces to open fire on protesters during the 18-day uprising that forced him to resign in February. Transcripts of prosecutors questioning Mubarak were published in two Egyptian newspapers but judicial officials confirmed the authenticity of the documents.<ref name="voanews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html |title=Egyptian Media: Mubarak Denies Ordering Police to Fire on Protesters | Middle East | English |publisher=Voanews.com |date=2011-07-14 |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> Mubarak says he issued clear instructions for police not to use force against people taking part in the protests against his three-decade autocratic rule. He denied charges that he ordered or had knowledge of security forces firing on the demonstrators.<ref name="voanews1"/>
â
On the 16 July, a member of Egypt's ruling military council briefly visited a protest camp in a central Cairo square, but left after protesters, some holding up shoes in anger, booed him off a stage. Maj. Gen. Tarek el-Mahdi had come to Tahrir Square to persuade a dozen demonstrators to end a hunger strike which had begun several days ago, but was forced to cut short his visit because of the heckling. El-Mahdi later told state TV that he was disappointed that a small crowd of protesters managed to drive him out of the square before he could reach the tent housing the hunger strikers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Deeb |first=Sarah El |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Senior Egyptian military official heckled - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> In the latest move to calm rising public anger, Prime Minister [[Essam Sharaf]] accepted the resignation of foreign minister Mohammed el-Orabi. Sharaf also appointed two new deputies, one of which was prominent economist, and former head of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Hazem el-Biblawi.<ref>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/</ref>
+
On the 16 July, a member of Egypt's ruling military council briefly visited a protest camp in a central Cairo square, but left after protesters, some holding up shoes in anger, booed him off a stage. Maj. Gen. Tarek el-Mahdi had come to Tahrir Square to persuade a dozen demonstrators to end a hunger strike which had begun several days ago, but was forced to cut short his visit because of the heckling. El-Mahdi later told state TV that he was disappointed that a small crowd of protesters managed to drive him out of the square before he could reach the tent housing the hunger strikers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Deeb |first=Sarah El |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Senior Egyptian military official heckled - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> In the latest move to calm rising public anger, Prime Minister [[Essam Sharaf]] accepted the resignation of foreign minister Mohammed el-Orabi. Sharaf also appointed two new deputies, one of which was prominent economist, and former head of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Hazem el-Biblawi.<ref>{{cite web|last=Deeb |first=Sarah El |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Senior Egyptian military official heckled - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref>
On the 17 July, Sharaf named 12 new Cabinet members. State TV dubbed the new government lineup the "Revolution Cabinet." Most of the ministers were relative newcomers which was seen as a way to avoid further criticism by the protesters. Even after the Cabinet reshuffle, many of the protesters in the square said they have no intention of calling off their sit-in, which had been in place for more than a week.<ref name="sfgate1">{{cite web|author=By SARAH EL DEEB, Associated Press |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL |title=Egypt military rulers name electoral council head |publisher=Sfgate.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> One of the prominent members of the "Revolution Cabinet" is the Chief of Antiquities [[Zahi Hawass]]. Hawass is a prominant member of Egypts archaeological community, but has been the target of protests himself. These protests were begun by archaeology students who accused him of falsely claiming publicity for himself and corruption.
On the 17 July, Sharaf named 12 new Cabinet members. State TV dubbed the new government lineup the "Revolution Cabinet." Most of the ministers were relative newcomers which was seen as a way to avoid further criticism by the protesters. Even after the Cabinet reshuffle, many of the protesters in the square said they have no intention of calling off their sit-in, which had been in place for more than a week.<ref name="sfgate1">{{cite web|author=By SARAH EL DEEB, Associated Press |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL |title=Egypt military rulers name electoral council head |publisher=Sfgate.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> One of the prominent members of the "Revolution Cabinet" is the Chief of Antiquities [[Zahi Hawass]]. Hawass is a prominant member of Egypts archaeological community, but has been the target of protests himself. These protests were begun by archaeology students who accused him of falsely claiming publicity for himself and corruption.
